messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 54 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Exploring End-to-End Differentiable Natural Logic Modeling

Paper Abstract: Abstract We explore end-to-end trained differentiable models that integrate natural logic with neural networks, aiming to keep the backbone of natural language reasoning based on the natural logic formalism while introducing subsymbolic vector representations and neural components. The proposed model adapts module networks to model natural logic operations, which is enhanced with a memory component to model contextual information. Experiments show that the proposed framework can effectively model monotonicity-based reasoning, compared to the baseline neural network models without built-in inductive bias for monotonicity-based reasoning. Our proposed model shows to be robust when transferred from upward to downward inference. We perform further analyses on the performance of the proposed model on aggregation, showing the effectiveness of the proposed subcomponents on helping achieve better intermediate aggregation performance.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 54 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 54"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Neural module networks",
        "Naturalli: Natural logic inference for common sense reasoning",
        "Combining natural logic and shallow reasoning for question answering",
        "A large annotated corpus for learning natural language inference",
        "Neural natural language inference models enhanced with external knowledge",
        "Enhanced lstm for natural language inference",
        "Recurrent neural network-based sentence encoder with gated attention for natural language inference",
        "Enhancing sentence embedding with generalized pooling",
        "The PASCAL recognising textual entailment challenge",
        "Neuro-symbolic= neural+ logical+ probabilistic",
        "Lifted rule injection for relation embeddings",
        "Bert: Pre-training of deep bidirectional transformers for language understanding",
        "Semantic-based regularization for learning and inference",
        "Logic tensor networks for semantic image interpretation",
        "Neural logic machines",
        "Learning explanatory rules from noisy data",
        "Neural-symbolic learning and reasoning: contributions and challenges",
        "Neural module networks for reasoning over text",
        "From language to programs: Bridging reinforcement learning and maximum marginal likelihood",
        "Recent progress on monotonicity",
        "Inclusion and exclusion in natural language",
        "Proceedings of the ACL-PASCAL Workshop on Textual Entailment and Paraphrasing",
        "Dynamic meta-embeddings for improved sentence representations",
        "Adam: A method for stochastic optimization",
        "Linguistics and natural logic",
        "Augmenting neural networks with first-order logic",
        "Modeling semantic containment and exclusion in natural language inference",
        "An extended model of natural logic",
        "Natural Language Inference",
        "Deepproblog: Neural probabilistic logic programming",
        "The Neuro-Symbolic Concept Learner: Interpreting Scenes, Words, and Sentences From Natural Supervision",
        "WordNet: An electronic lexical database",
        "A discrete hard em approach for weakly supervised question answering",
        "Differentiable reasoning on large knowledge bases and natural language",
        "Computing relative polarity for textual inference",
        "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
        "Deep contextualized word representations",
        "Probing natural language inference models through semantic fragments",
        "End-to-end differentiable proving",
        "Conceptnet 5.5: An open multilingual graph of general knowledge",
        "End-to-end memory networks",
        "Natural language inference with hierarchical bilstm max pooling architecture",
        "Studies on natural logic and categorial grammar",
        "Essays in logical semantics",
        "The semantics of variety in categorial grammar",
        "Language in Action: categories, lambdas and dynamic logic",
        "Nlprolog: Reasoning with weak unification for question answering in natural language",
        "Memory networks",
        "A semantic loss function for deep learning with symbolic knowledge",
        "Can neural networks understand monotonicity reasoning?",
        "Help: A dataset for identifying shortcomings of neural models in monotonicity reasoning",
        "Differentiable learning of logical rules for knowledge base reasoning",
        "Enhancing unsupervised pretraining with external knowledge for natural language inference",
        "Dynamic self-attention : Computing attention over words dynamically for sentence embedding"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 54 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Exploring End-to-End Differentiable Natural Logic Modeling, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
